node.title: Crystal Plasticity- Deformation gradient error
node.bodyText:
Below is the error message
�[31m
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "FEProblem".
Material property 'deformation_gradient', requested by 'crysp_phase0' is not defined on block 0
Material property 'crysrot', requested by 'crysp_phase0' is not defined on block 0
Material property 'deformation_gradient', requested by 'crysp_phase1' is not defined on block 0
Material property 'crysrot', requested by 'crysp_phase1' is not defined on block 0
Material property 'deformation_gradient', requested by 'crysp_phase2' is not defined on block 0
Material property 'crysrot', requested by 'crysp_phase2' is not defined on block 0

Hello
use Debug/show_material_props on an example input and find out which material is supposed to be declaring this
then check if you have this material in your simulation and that you are not passing parameters that would be changing the name of the property
Guillaume

So below is the .out after adding

show_material_props = true

hello
so the deformation_graident property name got prefixed with phase0 and phase1. Are you wanting to use a specific phase for that material property?
I just got this input script from a colleague and am trying to make it work. I can share the input script if you need to see it.

You’ll need to get context from them about this.
If they meant to use properties from a specific phase or were relying on some sort of homogenization between phases, the treatment will be different

Yes, it is for a nickel-chromium alloy that exhibits anisotropy. One of the issues is the precipitates(phases) have different crystal structures
.
Is there a way to use different slip systems with slip resistance in MOOSE?
In the same spatial regions? (Subdomains)

node.title: Solid mechanics library missing
node.bodyText: I discovered I do not have the solid mechanics library in my MOOSE repository.
The mentioned library is missing my application

Hello
the tensor mechanics module got renamed to solid mechanics a month or so ago
If you update moose you should see it
Guillaume
I see tensor mechanics in my MAKEFILE. I just built a new application
If you used a new-enough moose you should see solid_mechanics instead of tensor mechanics in the Makefile

@Emmanuel-324 -
It appears that your versions of WASP and MOOSE are not in sync, and WASP just needs to be updated.
If you are using conda packages for these components, you can update to the latest version by running:
conda update moose-dev

And if that does not work, then you can try to remove and reinstall a new moose conda environment with:
conda env remove -n moose -all
conda create -n moose moose-dev

If you are not using conda and are manually installing everything, you can run this from the MOOSE root:
./scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh

I would suggest to then clean up your repo with git clean -xfd before retrying the MOOSE build step.
Note that git clean -xfd will delete any uncommitted work, so make sure you save your changes first.
I am installing it through an HPC cluster. Do I follow the same process?

@Emmanuel-324 -
You will not be using the conda package for WASP on HPC, so you will just need to run this from the root of the MOOSE repo:
./scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh

That script should pull and build the correct version of WASP needed for your version of MOOSE, then you can build MOOSE.
And if the MOOSE build fails again after this, I suggest to commit your changes, run git clean -xfd, then try to build again.
I have git clean and rebuilt the WASP but the MOOSE build always fails

Do you go in the top folder, moose/ before running git clean?
Do you have wasp or moose related environment variables set that would make you find the wrong moose or wasp when building?
Has the error changed since the first time you posted?
Finally what version of moose are you using?

Yes i git clean in MOOSE folder.
"module reset
module load apps site/tinkercliffs/easybuild/setup
module load apps site/tinkercliffs-rome/easybuild/setup
module load OpenMPI CMake
export CC=mpicc CXX=mpicxx FC=mpif90 F90=mpif90 F77=mpif77
mamba activate python-stack" This is how I load my environment.
The error has not changed
I am installing the MOOSE through an HPC cluster. Currently, I am trying to restart the whole installation process again by deleting the moose folder

node.title: Determining the integration rules in the kernel
node.bodyText:
Hi，
When solving an equation with multiple variables, where the orders of these variables are specified in the input file, and the equation contains a nonlinear term involving the multiplication of multiple variables, how does MOOSE determine the integration rules for this nonlinear term within the kernel, such as the order of integration and the number of integration points?

Hello
The default quadrature is not selected based on the form of the equation. It is chosen to be a Gauss quadrature of order n to be able to integrate polynomial products (for example shape * test function). It's exact in 1D
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Executioner/Quadrature/index.html
Guillaume

After reading the link you provided, I'm still a bit confused. It says "we actually use a quadrature of order 2n+1, with n the order of the variables," which means if my variable's basis function is of the second order, then a quadrature rule is chosen to precisely satisfy 2*2+1=5, resulting in a 5th order polynomial. However, if I set different orders for several variables in the input file, for example, one variable is of the second order and another is of the third order, how is the quadrature determined?

Hello
We use the maximum quadrature order required, and we use it for all variables
see SystemBase::getMinQuadratureOrder() for polling the quadrature orders from variables
and
FEProblemBase::createQRules for polling each system for the quadrature order they need

So， If I want to manually specify the quadrature order instead of letting it be automatically determined in MOOSE, how should I do that? Can I simply call an interface in the kernel to set a specific quadrature order for different kernels?

Hello
you cannot specify different quadratures on a per kernel basis without rewriting computeResidual (instead of computeQpResidual) and being very careful with the re initialization of material properties and variable values.
We can do (spatial) block-dependent quadratures fairly easily inside the Executioner/Quadrature block
Guillaume

node.title: Adding sink and recombination to the Multi-phase poly-crystalline Allen-Cahn Kernel
node.bodyText: I am trying to add sink and recombination to the Multi-phase poly-crystalline Allen-Cahn Kernel. The top equation is the equation already used by MOOSE. The second equation is from: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0927025622004839#! and it adds vacancy production, vacancy-interstial recombination, and sink terms to the grand potential equation in terms of chemical potential. The "MaskedBodyForce" kernal is being used to create the vacancy production part h_m*s^o_v. Does moose have kernals that could be used to simulate the two other parts of the equation? I am new to MOOSE.

I don't think so, you'll probably have to create your own custom kernel. it will work seamlessly with the phase field module.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/examples/ex02_kernel.html
this was the video I watched to learn all of MOOSE's features a while back, it's 12 hrs long (took me a week) but it really is worth it:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2tJwBsYaLaI&list=PLHI-fE3lo53508O5k9nli7BNMNdxFQSF5&index=1&t=11789s

node.title: How to mesh 2 phase microstructure
node.bodyText:
I have a large number of square images. they are all binary images of 2 of the same phases in different blends. I want to simulate elastic deformation in them. my intention is to do a uniform mesh where each pixel is an element of my mesh. but how can I input an image (or numpy array for image) into moose. how will it assign different stiffness values depending on the location? Here is my code:
import numpy as np
import h5py
import os

def read_microstructure_from_hdf5(filepath, dataset_name="dataset"):
    with h5py.File(filepath, 'r') as file:
        microstructure_data = np.array(file[dataset_name][168])
    return microstructure_data

def generate_moose_input_file(input_file_path, image_dim):
    with open(input_file_path, 'w') as file:
        file.writelines([
            "[GlobalParams]\n",
            "  order = FIRST\n",
            "  family = LAGRANGE\n",
            "  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'\n",
            "  out_of_plane_strain = strain_zz\n",
            "[]\n\n",
            
            "[Mesh]\n",
            "  [./square]\n",
            "    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator\n",
            f"    dim = 2\n",
            f"    nx = {image_dim}\n",
            f"    ny = {image_dim}\n",
            "    elem_type = QUAD4\n",
            "  [../]\n",
            "[]\n\n",
            
            "[Variables]\n",
            "  [./disp_x]\n",
            "  [../]\n",
            "  [./disp_y]\n",
            "  [../]\n",
            "  [./strain_zz]\n",
            "  [../]\n",
            "[]\n\n",
            
            "[AuxVariables]\n",
            "  [./nl_strain_zz]\n",
            "    order = CONSTANT\n",
            "    family = MONOMIAL\n",
            "  [../]\n",
            "[]\n\n",
            
            "[Materials]\n",
            "  [./phase1]\n",
            "    type = GenericConstantMaterial\n",
            "    properties = 'E nu'\n",
            "    property_values = '500 0.2'\n",
            "  [../]\n",
            "  [./phase2]\n",
            "    type = GenericConstantMaterial\n",
            "    properties = 'E nu'\n",
            "    property_values = '6000 0.3'\n",
            "  [../]\n",
            "[]\n\n",
            
            "[BCs]\n",
            "  [./left]\n",
            "    type = DirichletBC\n",
            "    variable = disp_x\n",
            "    boundary = left\n",
            "    value = 0.0\n",
            "  [../]\n",
            "  [./bottom]\n",
            "    type = DirichletBC\n",
            "    variable = disp_y\n",
            "    boundary = bottom\n",
            "    value = 0.0\n",
            "  [../]\n",
            "[]\n\n",
            
            "[Executioner]\n",
            "  type = Steady\n",
            "  solve_type = 'NEWTON'\n",
            "  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'\n",
            "  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'\n",
            "  nl_rel_tol = 1e-5\n",
            "  nl_abs_tol = 1e-8\n",
            "  nl_max_its = 50\n",
            "[]\n\n",
            
            "[Outputs]\n",
            "  exodus = true\n",
            "[]\n\n",
        ])

def process_image_to_input_file(filepath, output_folder, dataset_name="dataset"):
    binary_image = read_microstructure_from_hdf5(filepath, dataset_name)
    image_dim = binary_image.shape[0]
    base_name = os.path.splitext(os.path.basename(filepath))[0]
    input_file_path = os.path.join(output_folder, f"{base_name}.i")

    generate_moose_input_file(input_file_path, image_dim)

def process_images_folder(folder_path, output_folder, dataset_name="dataset"):
    for file in os.listdir(folder_path):
        if not file.endswith('.h5') and not file.endswith('.hdf5'):
            continue
        filepath = os.path.join(folder_path, file)
        process_image_to_input_file(filepath, output_folder, dataset_name)

folder_path = ''
output_folder = ''
dataset_name = ""

process_images_folder(folder_path, output_folder, dataset_name)

Hello
you can use the PropertyReadFile user object to read a CSV of the values of a space dependent field. The CSV will have to be created upstream of moose
then a PiecewiseConstantFromCSV will be able to give the spatial values of these quantities anywhere in the mesh

So you are already creating the input through a python script here.
Processing the data into a CSV that gets loaded by the python-created script will also need to be done by a script.
i have a very large dataset of images, how should I go about creating the input file besides a python script?
Scripts are the way to go. Updated the text

MICRO2D_homogenized.txt
MICRO2D_homogenized_material_properties.csv
I keep getting errors like "stress not found in block 0" and other things not found in block 0.

Stress is a material property, which should be the defined by the appropriate Material object.
Starting from an example, you should be able to find the Material you should use. It s probably some sort of strain-stress relationship materisal

so these are artificial microstructures and so I won't be able to find the "material"  - hence the csv file so that I can define the young's modulus and poisson's ratio at each element. Hence I was thinking of creating a custom material but I guess this is not the way to go?
[UserObjects]
[./read_properties]
type = PropertyReadFile
prop_file_name = '/storage/coda1/p-skalidindi7/0/shared/MOOSE/MICRO2D_homogenized_mat_prop.csv'
read_type = 'element'
nprop = 4
[../]
[./stress]
type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
[../]
[]
[Functions]
[./youngs_modulus]
type = PiecewiseConstantFromCSV
read_prop_user_object = read_properties
read_type = 'element'
column_number = 2
[../]
[./poissons_ratio]
type = PiecewiseConstantFromCSV
read_prop_user_object = read_properties
read_type = 'element'
column_number = 3
[../]
[]
[Materials]
[./elastic_properties]
type = CustomElasticMaterial
youngs_modulus_function = youngs_modulus
poissons_ratio_function = poissons_ratio
[../]
[]

Hello
this looks fine to me for having element dependent material properties.
you do need to be able to generate a CSV file ahead of the simulation
Guillaume

node.title: Injection and extraction cycles
node.bodyText:
Hello!
I'm trying to define a geothermal reservoir using Porous flow. In the current file I have only 1 well that is producing. For that I'm using the PorousFlowPolyLineSink, for both mass and heat extraction. I allow the system to reach equilibrium and the Dirac Kernels only start after t=0. I'm using a ConditionalFunctionEnableControl for this
For the production, I set the flow positive, to extract. I see a decrease of the pressure around the well but, for some reason, the temperature increases around the well for the first steps. Later, the temperature decreases around the well, increases a bit further and then comes back to the initial temperature. Shouldn't I only see decrease of temperature?
[DiracKernels]
  [production_T]
    type = PorousFlowPolyLineSink
    variable = temperature
    SumQuantityUO = extracted_heat
    point_file = point_130m.bh
    fluid_phase = 0
    p_or_t_vals = 0
    fluxes = 0.6 # 2Kg/s over 6m well
    use_enthalpy = true
  []
  [production_P]
    type = PorousFlowPolyLineSink
    variable = porepressure
    SumQuantityUO = extracted_mass
    point_file = point_130m.bh
    p_or_t_vals = 0
    fluxes = 0.3 # 2Kg/s over 6m well
  []
[]

I'm attaching the input and the point files.
I would really appreciate if someone could take a look at this. Thank you
PF_THM_Prod_1yr.zip

Hello
This doesnt look too physical indeed.
Is the result converged?
I see
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-6
  nl_rel_step_tol = 1e-4

in the executioner which is potentially accepting unconverged solutions. Especially with automatic scaling as the residual for each variables are scaled
Is this something you could solve without the mechanics part first? To see if the temperature problem is well converged
Guillaume

Hello! Thanks for replying and for the suggestions.
The model seemed to be converging. Most NL values were in the 1e-5 to 1e-8 orders, and the temperature residuals were much lower than the pressure ones.
I removed the mechanics part and now I'm only doing TH and I also reduced the tolerance. Still, I'm getting the same result.
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
  nl_rel_step_tol = 1e-8
  l_tol = 1e-8

I reduced the element size, just to test it and it did not have much effect. By removing the automatic scaling, the convergence is better, both variable residuals are in the order of 1e-12 now but the issue with the temperature is still there.
For what I read in some other discussions, the PorousFlowPolyLineSink is a very good option to simulate geothermal production, right? Or is there a better solution for the heat extraction? I know that for injection one should use other options.
Thank you again
PF_TH_Prod.zip

Hi @clariu25
First, i would recommend to run the model with only one injection point, to make it easy for understanding and interpretation.
Have you tried to apply heat source using BC rather than direckernel?
Rahim

node.title: Outputting a .vtk file for a simple example not working
node.bodyText:
I have an input file (see below) titled pressure_diffusion.i. I'm trying to output .vtk file types (as I'm interested in then converting the .vtk file to a .msh file for a project using meshio). Currently, I do this by setting vtk = true in the [Outputs] section within the input file. However, when I execute the input file, I don't get a .vtk file. Instead I get four files titled: pressure_diffusion_out_001.pvtu, pressure_diffusion_out_001_0.vtu, pressure_diffusion_out_000.pvtu and pressure_diffusion_out_000_0.vtu. This link (link: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Outputs/index.html) says that VTK output types require --enable-vtk "when building libMesh", but I don't know what this means?
How can I output a .vtk file type which I can then convert to a .msh file using some other intermediate file conversion package?
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh # Can generate simple lines, rectangles and rectangular prisms
  dim = 2 # Dimension of the mesh
  nx = 100 # Number of elements in the x direction
  ny = 10 # Number of elements in the y direction
  xmax = 0.304 # Length of test chamber
  ymax = 0.0257 # Test chamber radius
[]

[Problem]
  type = FEProblem # This is the "normal" type of Finite Element Problem in MOOSE
  coord_type = RZ # Axisymmetric RZ
  rz_coord_axis = X # Which axis the symmetry is around
[]

[Variables]
  [pressure]
    # Adds a Linear Lagrange variable by default
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [diffusion]
    type = ADDiffusion # Laplacian operator
    variable = pressure # Operate on the "pressure" variable from above
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [inlet]
    type = ADDirichletBC # Simple u=value BC
    variable = pressure # Variable to be set
    boundary = left # Name of a sideset in the mesh
    value = 4000 # (Pa) From Figure 2 from paper. First data point for 1mm spheres.
  []
  [outlet]
    type = ADDirichletBC
    variable = pressure
    boundary = right
    value = 0 # (Pa) Gives the correct pressure drop from Figure 2 for 1mm spheres
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady # Steady state problem
  solve_type = NEWTON # Perform a Newton solve

  # Set PETSc parameters to optimize solver efficiency
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type' # PETSc option pairs with values below
  petsc_options_value = ' hypre    boomeramg'
[]

[Outputs]
  vtk = true
[]

Hello
There are a few VTK-like formats. vtk, vtu, pvtu etc.
I think the VTK documentation describes them better than I can. We output pvtu to be able to perform parallel IO.
Hopefully meshio can convert .pvtus. If not the paraview can be used to convert to something meshio can read
Guillaume

node.title: Can MOOSE output STL files of the system under consideration?
node.bodyText: I'm developing a project where I'd like MOOSE to output an STL file of the system under consideration? I will start by using a .msh file created with Gmsh, but then I intend to perform topology optimisation on the system, and I want to output an STL file of the topology optimised component. Is this possible?

Hello
We dont have this capability.
I think reading a STL then meshing it is more within our interests currently than outputting STLs.
So if you want to do this, you ll need to implement it yourself.
Guillaume

Thanks for your swift response. So would I at least be able to get the .msh file of the outputted component and then you’re saying I’d have to produce some code that converts the outputted .msh file into an STL file? Where can I find a list of mesh file types (e.g., .msh) outputted by MOOSE so I can potentially explore other options if converting from .msh to STL is not possible?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/FileMeshGenerator.html has a list
I added it for convenience but otherwise there s another list under the Outputs syntax

So just to be clear, I should be able to write my final topology optimized component to a .msh ASCII file (as suggested below)? I'm unsure as below it says that 'these formats... could be easily added to MOOSE' - does this mean I'd have to somehow do some extra steps to add the capability of writing a .msh ASCII file in MOOSE?

Hello
Yes libmesh can write with these formats but moose cannot for now. So you need to create a new MOOSE output object that uses the libmesh APIs to trigger an output of the moose mesh to a gmsh .msh.
This should be fairly straightforward to do but it s C++ work so you should have followed one of the development tutorials
Guillaume

@GiudGiud you mentioned that reading in an STL and meshing it is something being investigated by MOOSE. I'm currently trying to convert a binary STL file to a MSH ASCII file using the 'gmsh'/'meshio' libraries but not having any luck - do you know a way around this problem?

Hello
STL is not usually convertible to a mesh file without specialized meshing software. i think gmsh should be able to do it. otherwise, you can use Cubit. If you work for a university there is a student version (of coreform cubit, a private company's product), if you work for a US government contractor, there is a release version (of regular cubit) by Sandia National Lab.
Guillaume

Hi @GiudGiud,
You said the following above:

Yes libmesh can write with these formats but moose cannot for now. So you need to create a new MOOSE output object that uses the libmesh APIs to trigger an output of the moose mesh to a gmsh .msh.

Is there an easy to follow example where someone has done this (i.e., created a MOOSE app that uses the libmesh APIs to trigger an output of the MOOSE mesh to a gmsh .msh file)? Hello
There isnt a tutorial on creating a new Outputs object.
However, Exodus, Tecplot, etc most of the outputs are exactly that, a MOOSE object using libmesh APIs.
The code in libmesh is there
https://github.com/libMesh/libmesh/blob/devel/src/mesh/gmsh_io.C
we just need to call it from MOOSE
Guillaume
